awd_titl_txt: Novel Motility and Protein Secretion Machinery of Flavobacterium Johnsoniae
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract
Intellectual merit:
Cells of Flavobacterium johnsoniae crawl over surfaces by a process known as gliding motility. These cells do not have well-studied motility organelles such as flagella or Type IV pili.  Instead they rely on a novel motility machine composed of proteins that are unique to the phylum Bacteroidetes.  Twenty-four proteins involved in motility have been identified. These include 1) Gld proteins that are components of the gliding 'motor', 2) mobile cell surface adhesins (SprB, RemA, and others) that appear to be propelled by the 'motor' and may function somewhat like a tank tread, and 3) components of a novel protein secretion system (PorSS) that is required for assembly of SprB on the cell surface.  Electron microscopic observations suggest that SprB may form long filaments extending from the cell.  SprB and RemA allow movement of cells on different surfaces, and they have lectin-like carbohydrate-binding domains that may facilitate binding to these surfaces.  Cells with mutations in genes involved in polysaccharide synthesis and export also result in motility defects.  These results suggest a model for gliding in which the gliding 'motors' propel adhesive filaments along the cell surface.  Cells express different adhesins (SprB, RemA and others) to allow movement on different surfaces, and exopolysaccharides might enhance motility by coating the surfaces and interacting with the adhesins.  Genetic, cell biology, biochemical, and electron microscopic approaches will be used to address 3 specific aims related to the cell-surface components of the motility machinery.  
Specific Aim 1.  Characterize the mobile cell-surface adhesins involved in gliding.  Antibodies against RemA will be used to test the hypothesis that RemA is a mobile cell-surface protein and to determine if the PorSS is required for secretion of RemA.  Fluorescently labeled epitope-tagged RemA will also be used to visualize dynamic changes that occur during cell movement.  The effect of soluble sugars on RemA function will be analyzed to determine the binding specificity of the lectin domain.  Recombinant versions of RemA will be generated to determine the functions of individual domains of the protein, and cryo-electron microscopy tomography will be used to test the hypothesis that RemA and SprB are components of different cell-surface filaments.
Specific Aim 2.  Determine the role of extracellular polysaccharides in gliding.  Wza and Wzc are components of the putative exopolysaccharide secretion system linked to gliding.  Exopolysaccharides will be isolated and characterized.  Cells with mutations in wza and wzc will be analyzed to test the hypothesis that they are deficient in exopolysaccharides.  Purified polysaccharides will be used to determine if they interact with the lectin domain of RemA and extracellular complementation will determine if exogenously supplied polysaccharide overcomes the motility defects of wza and wzc mutants.  
Specific Aim 3.  Characterize the protein secretion system involved in assembly of the cell-surface adhesins.  Genetic approaches will be used to identify additional components of the PorSS involved in protein secretion and to determine the features of secreted proteins that target them to this system.  Protein-protein interactions will be studied to address questions related to structure and function of the PorSS.

Broader Impacts:
Undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral scientists will conduct the research.  Students will gain experience in genetics, molecular biology, and modern light and electron microscopic approaches to study questions of bacterial cell biology.  The projects are well suited to expose students to a broad array of techniques.  Students and postdoctoral scientists will receive extensive training in scientific writing and in presentation techniques.  Research on F. johnsoniae will be incorporated into several undergraduate laboratory courses.  Undergraduate students will have primary responsibility for constructing and characterizing mutations in potential components of the PorSS.  Research results will be reported by students at national meetings and published in leading journals, and genetic tools developed for F. johnsoniae and related bacteria will be made available to the scientific community.  Similar gliding motility and protein secretion machines are found in many members of the phylum Bacteroidetes, including bacteria of environmental and agricultural importance.  Some of these bacteria are important pathogens of fish that impact aquaculture systems, and others have novel mechanisms for digesting cellulose and may aid conversion of plant material into biofuels.  An improved understanding of F. johnsoniae motility and protein secretion may thus have practical applications.

This research explored the novel machinery that allows bacteria such as Flavobacterium johnsoniae to crawl rapidly over surfaces by a process known as gliding motility. Our results demonstrated that the bacteria move adhesins rapidly along their cell surfaces. These proteins may function similar to the treads of a tank to result in cell movement. The protein components of the motility machinery were identified by genetic, molecular biology, biochemical, and microscopic approaches. One of these proteins, SprB, is a cell-surface adhesin involved in gliding. Fluorescently labeled SprB was propelled rapidly along the length of the cell by motors embedded in the cell envelope. Attachment of SprB to a surface resulted in cell movement over that surface. Mutants lacking SprB retained some residual motility. We identified a second motility adhesin, RemA, that was responsible for much of this motility. RemA moved rapidly on the cell surface similar to SprB. The different adhesins (SprB, RemA, and others) allow cells to move over many different surfaces. Assembly of the gliding motility machinery involves a unique protein secretion system, the type IX secretion system (T9SS). The T9SS delivers proteins across the bacterial outer membrane. We demonstrated that the motility adhesins SprB and RemA are delivered to the cell surface by this system. We also identified dozens of other cell surface and extracellular proteins that are secreted by the T9SS. The components of the F. johnsoniae secretion system and the mechanism by which proteins are targeted for secretion were determined. A carboxy-terminal region of secreted proteins was necessary and sufficient for secretion by the T9SS. Fusion of this region to foreign proteins resulted in their secretion by F. johnsoniae cells. Many motility mutants are deficient in T9SS function, suggesting that the motility machinery and the T9SS are intertwined. To begin to untangle motility and secretion we identified several nonmotile mutants that were competent for secretion.

F. johnsoniae belongs to the large and diverse phylum Bacteroidetes. We performed genome analyses that suggest that many members of this phylum have T9SSs and use these to secrete numerous proteins. T9SSs have been linked to the ability of some of these bacteria to cause disease. Comparative analyses of the gliding and secretion machines of members of this phylum identified conserved features and highlighted the roles of individual proteins in motility and secretion. During the course of this study we developed methods to efficiently construct gene deletion mutations in F. johnsoniae. We also adapted these tools for use in many other members of the phylum Bacteroidetes. Bacteroidetes are common and important in many environments, including in and on the human body. Some of these bacteria cause disease and others have potential practical uses such as assisting in the conversion of cellulose into biofuels. Use of the gene deletion techniques to study these bacteria thus has potential practical value.
